Does anyone dispute the basic premise of Charles Darwin's 'theory of evolution' in modern science? To be sure we are talking about the same topic, in science, theories are proven to work explanations of facts and observations. In lay use, a “theory” means, “here’a an idea or what I think happened” , a wild guess, etc. So, evolution itself is not a theory. Evolution is an observed fact. The theory that explains how it works, in nature, is called “Natural Selection”. No one who understand what evolution is, or how it works, disputes evolution, or, for that matter, natural selection. It is possible to understand what evolution is, and how it works in agriculture for example, but not in nature. That is what Lamarck, etc, had been TRYING to do. They knew about evolution, they knew how it worked in agriculture, breeding crops and livestocks to get desired traits, etc… .. but, could not come up with a working explanation as to how it worked in nature… with no farmer choosing who gets to breed. Darwin’s premise was very very simple, the way most brilliant ideas seem, once someone describes them. His premise was basically that in nature, instead of a farmer deciding which individuals reproduce to get traits the farmer wanted, nature did. So, all that happened was that parent’s the survived to reproduce, had whatever traits worked, in nature. So, the offspring inherited whatever traits worked. And that is it in a nutshell… that is the premise… called “Natural Selection”. :D
